dypvwe6.Author: WhyDontYouTryIt
dypvwe6.Text:
Bitcoin doesn't need to achieve that. Bitcoin is just a protocol.

Other services can and will achieve that, using Bitcoin. Yes there's still work to be done, but if there's money to be made, the work will be done.

And it isn't about centralization. Bitcoin is decentralized. Period.

Other services might be centralized for a time, but competition will drive the decentralisation of those services.

dyq9zj6.Author: ArcticRhombus
dyq9zj6.Text:
It is for noobs. It is a good place to get your feet wet with 50 bucks and get comfortable with addresses, sending payments back and forth etc.

However, if you don't know the secret code that proves you control that unit of Bitcoin, you are always at the mercy of the secret code holder (Coinbase) going bankrupt, stealing your Bitcoin, being commanded by the government to not pay out your Bitcoin, et cetera. That's why people say: not your private keys, not your Bitcoin.

Coinbase is essentially acting like a bank, saying "don't you worry your pretty little head about hard things like secret codes. We'll take care of that for you." Just like a bank stores your cash and valuables. It's a lot of trust to give them.

dyp5ubt.Text:
I strongly caution anyone doing this to only day trade a small percentage of your stack. I only do 10% for fun. 

Think how you would feel if you sell a lot of your stack at the tip and then all of a sudden a giant green dildo appears and the price jumps over 1k (it just happened a few weeks ago). Then you miss out.  With institutional investors getting ready to jump on the train this could happen unpredictably and the jumps could be even more dramatic.

dyqb6hn.Author: ArcticRhombus
dyqb6hn.Text:
Yes. 2 things: 
1. Banks (in the USA) are federally insured. I don't think Coinbase is. So bankruptcy or theft is covered by the government for a bank.
2. Part of the fundamental guiding principle of many early Bitcoin pioneers is that the current banking system, where banks are free to lend out the money deposited, and only keep a tiny bit available for withdrawal, is immoral. It creates a danger of bank runs causing insolvency, and encourages banks to take wild risks with depositor money, knowing that they will be bailed out by the government if they go bust. The bank acts like it merely stores your money, but really, that money is gone. Some people believe that's a fundamentally unethical business model. If your money can be seized or confiscated, is it really yours?
